Summary: SC for 15.2: Instabilities found within snowpack on W to N aspects above 900m. Esp gully tops and coire rims. Cornices. Moderate Haz
SnowDistribution: Little snow below 650m with accumulations gaining depth with altitude gain.  Cloudy on the tops with some bright spells during the afternoon.  Winds approx 10-20 mph.
Comment: Expect the redistribution of existing unconsolidated snow from mid mountain level through the forecast period.  Significant snowfall expected on Sunday.
WeatherInfluences: A dry day is expected with the exception of some light snowfall during the afternoon.  It will remain cold with the freezing level around 200 metres, rising to 400 metres in the afternoon.  Winds will be fresh from the South-South-East with a lull for a few hours in the early hours before backing East and becoming fresh once again.
SnowStability: Instabilities within the snowpack will persist on West and North-West aspects above 900 metres. Localised areas of unstable windslab will develop through the forecast period on mainly North aspects also above 900 metres. Areas most affected will be steep wind sheltered locations such as gully tops and coire rims.  Cornices will be found on West to North aspects. The old snow will be icy, hard with good stability. The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A light dusting of fresh snow at all levels overnight cleared to leave a dry day with bright spells developing during the afternoon.  Winds were fresh from the South-East.  The freezing was at 200 meters at midday.
ObservedSnowStability: Instabilities within the snowpack are present on West and North-West aspects above 900 metres. Areas most affected are coire rims, gully tops and other steep wind sheltered locations. Accumulations of fresh unstable windslab was identified on North and North-East aspects but these are shallow in nature and isolated. The old snow pack is firm with good stability. Cornices can be found on West through North to North-East aspects and remain a threat from collapse. The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

Summary: TO 15/2. Remaining dry with strong Easterly winds. Patchy snow cover above 750m, firm and stable in all locations. Low Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Sparse snow cover mostly bare ground. Good visibility.  Winds approx 10mph with slightly stronger gusts.
Comment: A considerable wind chill is expected with the strengthening Easterly airflow. Patches of water ice are present at higher elevations with some paths affected.
WeatherInfluences: It will be dry and cloudy. Easterly or South-Easterly winds will steadily increase from the early hours and are expected to reach strong to gale force during the afternoon. The overnight freezing level will be around 200 metres, rising to around 400 metres during the day.
SnowStability: The patchy snow cover will remain firm and stable in all locations. Greatest snow cover will be mostly in mountain areas inland from the coastal ranges and on Northerly to Easterly aspects above 750 metres. Snow will be mainly confined to coire rims, ridge flanks and gullies. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A dry and sunny day, cloudier in the afternoon. Light to moderate East-South-Easterly winds. The freezing level was around 400 metres.
ObservedSnowStability: The patchy snow cover is firm and stable in all locations. The snow surface softened slightly in wind sheltered areas exposed to the sun. Greatest snow cover is mostly in mountain areas inland from the coastal ranges and on Northerly to Easterly aspects above 750 metres. Snow is mainly confined to coire rims, ridge flanks and gullies. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: LO for 15/2. Little changes, a few minor instabilities on N to E aspects above 1150m. Elsewhere generally stable. Low hazard.
SnowDistribution: Main snowpack above 700m, various patches of water-ice about.  Good visibility.  Winds 20-30 mph and feeling cold.
Comment: Little change in both weather and snowpack until early next week.
WeatherInfluences: More of the same weather wise. Mainly dry, although a few light snow showers are possible, and a strong East-South-Easterly breeze. Again there may not be a well defined freezing level. However, temperatures will generally remain below freezing in most mountain locations.
SnowStability: A few minor instabilities will remain in the deposits of old windslab at the top of North to East facing slopes and gullies above 1150 metres. In other locations stability will be generally good.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: It was another dry day with near gale South-Easterly winds at higher levels. Although there was not a well defined freezing level, temperatures were generally below freezing in the hills.
ObservedSnowStability: A few isolated instabilities remain at the top of slopes and gullies above 1150 metres on North to East aspects. These areas are not extensive. On other aspects and lower altitudes stability is generally good.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: CM for 15.2: Limited thin new windslab on W to N aspects. Good general stability. Low Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Breakable crust in places, firm snow ice elsewhere. Good visibility.  Winds 20-30 mph progress difficult at times with stronger gusts
Comment: Full car park at Creag Meagaidh on Friday.
WeatherInfluences: Dry overnight then some brief very light snow showers during the morning. Remaining cold throughout. Light later moderate East-South-East winds.
SnowStability: Good stability in most locations. A little new windslab is possible on steep West to North aspects above 950m. Any new accumulations expected to be very thin and limited in extent. Minor pre existing cold induced instabilities will remain on selected steep North to East aspects above 1000m.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Dry and bright. Cold, especially in heavily shaded areas though milder in the sun.
ObservedSnowStability: Stability is generally good. Localised instabilities are persisting, mainly on steep North to East aspects above 1000 metres. Some old cornices remain, mainly above North through East to South-East aspects. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: GC for 15/2/25. Snowpack stability will remain good. Fresh snow accumulations are not expected to be significant. Low hazard.
SnowDistribution: Variable snow condition. Good visibility  Winds around 20 mph fresh, cooling.
WeatherInfluences: It will remain cold with moderate East-South-East winds overnight increasing through the day. A little light snow is expected overnight but otherwise dry.
SnowStability: Snowpack stability will remain good. Fresh snow accumulations are not expected to be significant. Greatest accumulations will remain on North to East aspects above 800 metres. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: It was a cold dry day with fresh South-Easterly winds.
ObservedSnowStability: Snowpack stability is generally good. The few, isolated, shallow deposits of windslab that persist on high North to East aspects are well bonded. A breakable crust exists in many locations, with the snow surface firm and icy in other locations. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: NC for 15.2: Unstable windslab, W, NW, N, NE aspects above 900m. Fragile cornices. Elsewhere firm stable. Moderate Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Icy paths and hillsides, leeward slopes and plateaus wind scoured. Generally, good visibility apart from a cloud cap over the Northern corries, this cleared by mid afternoon.   Winds 20-30 mph, stronger at lower levels making  progress difficult at times.
Comment: Very firm snow ice with serious run out potential on steep slopes.  Biting wind with high wind chill.
WeatherInfluences: Fresh South-South-Easterly winds will become South-South-Easterly in direction by the afternoon and increase to strong.  A trace of new snow at dawn but otherwise it\'s expected to be dry. Remaining cold with a freezing level around 300 to 400 metres.
SnowStability: Unstable windslab will continue to develop on West through North to North-East aspects above 900 metres.  Areas most affected will be wind sheltered locations such as coire rims, gullies and crag aprons. Fragile cornices will overhang some of these aspects. Elsewhere the snowpack will be firm and stable, with plateau areas mostly scoured.  The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A dry day with strong to gale force Southerly winds. The midday freezing level was around 600 metres.
ObservedSnowStability: Accumulations of unstable windslab continued to develop on North-West to North-East aspects above 900 metres. Areas most affected are in steep wind sheltered locations such as coire rims, gully tops and convexities. Localised cross-loaded deposits are also present elsewhere in gullies, and on crag aprons due to the strong winds. Elsewhere the snow is firm and stable, and plateau areas  mostly scoured. Fragile cornices remain above some Northerly aspects.  The avalanche hazard is Moderate.
